column4: hello, i have a question what does the file "/proc/modules" do for my system and is it important, because i am getting errors when working with it
you would only read that file ...

i was trying to read it with gedit and i got the error "The file /proc/modules changed on disk.", the reason i am trying to open it is because i am looking for a line that i think should be there but something else says is not there
it does change, and gedit is only letting you know it did. You won't be saving the file, so it's not an error
but when i reload it, that is the option that it gives me i see nothing in there and shouldn't there be something in there? or what is it for?
does this modules file have any connections to modules.dep
as bruenig pointed out, lsmod shows you the same information. I think a better thing would be for you to explain what you're trying to do, someone might have some help then
sudo modprobe usbhid
/proc/modules is a list of kernel modules that are currently installed into the kernel, should have added that earlier
isn't that the opposite of "sudo rmmod usbhid" which in the tutorial it tells me to do so that buttons on the mouse act like buttons on a keyboard (i think that is what it does)
yes, it is the opposite. And that would be a possible result, I guess.  sudo modprobe -r usbhid would be the preferred way rather than rmmod
so the script is expecting usbhid and trying to remove it, but it's not already loaded into the kernel, causing that error?

so then i should change the line in my script file that the tutorial had me make to "sudo modprobe -r usbhid" and then just ignore the error about it not be able to unload it because it isn't load in the first place?
sounds right without reading the script.
ok ill do that and it sounds fine thank you
gconf-editor /apps/nautilus/preferences/enable_delete
thank you that was what i was looking for
http://www.linuxquestions.org/questions/debian-26/dynamic-mmap-ran-out-of-room-error-when-adding-new-apt-source-list-233417/#post1188874 , I'd make a fresh file in /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/ myslef
i had tried that and then i was getting an error that said "there was extra junk on line 1"
ah, I just got that for the options, it shouldn't have quote marks
I'll look for a different one to bookmark, thanks
